ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned a lot of techniques and concepts that are fundamental to my research in robotics that I will continue to employ
I gained knowledge about planning and optimization algorithms.

I learned about discrete- and continuous-space planning (DFS, BFS, A*, Dijkstra, PRM, RRT, logic-based planners), matrix methods for optimization (matrix math, single-value decomposition), and iterative methods for optimization (trust-region methods, quasi-Newton methods, etc.). Because the class was so well-organized and the problem sets were good, I actually feel that I have a good grip on almost all the material we covered, which isn't always the case for STEM classes.
Discrete-space planning, continuous-space planning, matrix operation in optimization, general optimization
I learned about a variety of planning algorithms as well as optimization strategies and the math underlying them.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The notes and lectures were extremely informative and conducive to further learning. Also, the office hours were very easy to schedule and very helpful for the assignments.
The lectures can be made a bit more interactive.

Strengths: Professor Rakita's course notes were probably the best I've ever seen, and they were incredibly useful in learning and reviewing the material. The workload wasn't too high, but it forced me to engage with the content enough to understand it well. The programming assignments provided us with code to animate our algorithms, which facilitated easier debugging, more learning, and more enjoyment.
Weaknesses: I wish we'd spent just a little less time on discrete planning, which I'd already seen in multiple courses, so we could have spent more time on the more novel aspects of the class, like continuous optimization.

This is one of the best CS courses I have taken. The course is very well-organized, including four written assignment, four coding assignment, midterm, final, and project. The notes are super helpful to understand the course materials. Also the professor is a very good person and helps you if you have any questions about the course material or the assignment.
The course was well structured and lectures were very clear and easy to follow.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! This course is great if the topics of planning and optimization are interesting to you or are relevant to your research.

Yes, definitely. Professor Rakita is very organized and very good at explaining concepts. Without having to go above and beyond the required work for this class, I feel that I left it with a clear, in-depth understanding of the topics we covered, which is a testament to Professor Rakita's good teaching and structuring. The course notes on Notion are amazing.
strongly recommend if you are interested in optimization
I would definitely recommend this course if you are interested in starting to learn about planning and optimization, especially for robotics.
